awd_titl_txt: Developing, unifying, and empirically testing theory for inducible and evolving defenses
awd_abstract_narration:
Throughout the world, prey species have a variety of defenses to avoid being eaten by predators. Plastic defenses are those that can change over time based on how many predators are present, for example prey may spend more time hiding when there are more predators around. Evolving defenses (like shell thickness) change over time based on which parents survive to reproduce and are able to pass their traits to their offspring. These different types of defenses influence the abundances of prey and their predators, as well as responses to environmental change. However, it is unclear exactly what effects plastic and evolving defenses have and whether plastic and evolving defenses have similar or different effects on species abundances and their responses to environmental change. Developing such an understanding is important because humans are dramatically altering environments through nutrient enrichment and species mortality. At present, it is not possible to predict how different types of defense (plastic or evolving) determine how populations will respond. This project uses laboratory experiments and mathematical models to determine how different types of plastic and evolving defenses influence population abundances and how populations respond to environmental change. This research program will train undergraduate and graduate students in the fields of community ecology and mathematical biology, engage underrepresented minorities in research, and engage the public through community outreach activities. 

Adaptive responses in prey to predation pressure can be plastic or evolutionary in nature, and both can alter the dynamics and stability of ecological communities. The goal of this project is to develop theory that explains how mechanistic differences between different types of plastic defenses and evolving defenses shape the dynamics of communities. To identify when plastic and evolving defenses have similar versus different effects, mathematical models will be developed to explain how plastic and evolving defenses influence system stability and population responses to nutrient enrichment and species mortality. The theory will be tested via laboratory based experiments involving populations of a prey species (Paramecium) that do or do not have plastic defenses - changes in behavior and body width - that alter the rate at which they are consumed by predators. This work will both extend current theory for plastic defenses and unify it with the theory for evolving defenses. The theory-data pairing approach of this project is likely to generate important advances in the theory of plastic defenses and community ecology. This work will also yield insight into the connections between plastic and evolutionary adaptation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Most animal and plant species are consumed by other organisms; the consumer is called a predator and the animal or plant being consumed is called the prey.  To avoid being eaten, many prey species have evolving defenses or inducible defenses.  In populations with evolving defenses, individual prey have different, fixed levels of defense that are inherited from their parents.  In populations with inducible defenses, the defense levels of the prey increase when predators are present and decrease when predators are absent.  This project integrated mathematical theory and experiments to understand how the differences between evolving and inducible defenses affect the abundances of prey and their predators and how those abundances respond to environmental change.  

 

We developed models of evolving and inducible defenses and compared their structures.  We showed that the models have a similar structure, but differences arise between the models depending on the timing, reversibility, and cues triggering the inducible defenses. These results helped unify the theories for evolving and inducible defense and provided a conceptual framework for comparing the effects of inducible and evolving defenses on the abundances of predators and prey. 

 

We used the mathematical models to explore how evolving and inducible defenses affect the abundances of prey and predators. We showed that evolving defenses can cause prey and predator abundances to continuously fluctuate over time and we showed that evolving defenses alter the responses to environmental change (via predator mortality or nutrient enrichment); both of these occur under a wide range of conditions, including when defense is under disruptive selection.  In comparison, we showed that inducible defenses can also cause fluctuations in abundances and alter responses to environmental change, but those effects occur less frequently. Indeed, we showed that those effects are most likely to occur when (a) prey over-express defense, meaning the defenses levels are much greater than is necessary or (b) prey respond to many cues, including cues from predators and other prey.  This theory helps explain why population fluctuations and altered responses to environmental change occur more frequently in prey populations with evolving defenses than with inducible defenses.  

 

Our theoretical results show the range of possible effects evolving and inducible defenses can have on predator and prey abundances.  We also used laboratory experiments to show what effects evolving and inducible defenses actually have in a microbial community. In our experiments, the predator is the flatworm Stenostonum, the prey is the protist Paramecium, and the food for the prey are bacteria. Prey defense is body width: wider prey are consumed by predators at a slower rate than thinner prey. Our experiments compared (a) communities with inducible defenses, meaning all prey had inducible defenses and (b) communities with evolving defenses, meaning individual prey had fixed, heritable levels of defense.  Matching our theoretical predictions about fluctuations in prey and predator abundances, we showed that communities with evolving defenses have larger fluctuations than populations with inducible defenses. This work shows that just the mode of adaptation (evolution versus induction) can influence how prey defense affects species abundances in empirical systems. 

 

To explain these differing effects of evolving and inducible defenses in our laboratory system, we used additional experiments to show how increased body width reduces predator consumption rates and what factors cause body width to increase. We showed that increased body width does not reduce encounters between prey and predators, but instead increased body width increases the amount of time it takes for predators to handle and consume prey.  We also showed that prey defense levels are affected by multiple cues: defense levels increase when predators are present, but the defense levels are lower when prey are more abundant or the bacterial food is more abundant.  Complementing these results from laboratory microbial communities, we used field experiments to show how inducible defenses in a natural system depend on predator presence and food availability. In these field experiments, insects lay eggs in the leaf wells of bromeliads (a plant) and the insect’s defense is the avoidance of wells where the eggs are likely to be eaten by predators.  In qualitative agreement with our results from our laboratory experiments, we showed that the insects typically avoid wells where predators are present, but the prey will lay eggs in wells where resource availability is high. Combined, our laboratory and field studies demonstrate that prey allocate resources to inducible defenses based on multiple cues that provide information about their predators, competitors, and food availability. 

 

To date, the project has produced three peer-reviewed publications, five more papers nearing completion, and future papers in development. Several graduate and undergraduate students were trained in experimental ecology and ecological and evolutionary theory.  In addition, components of this work were developed into curriculum activities for college courses and hand-on activities and presentations for local communities in Utah.
